name: Potassium
summary: Potassium is an essential mineral and electrolyte critical for nerve transmission, muscle contraction, cardiovascular health, and fluid balance. Supplementation is mainly used to treat deficiency states.
description: Potassium is the primary intracellular cation, playing a vital role in maintaining fluid balance, acid-base homeostasis, neuromuscular function, and cardiac rhythm. It is widely obtained from dietary sources such as fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains. Deficiency (hypokalemia) can result from diuretic use, gastrointestinal losses, or chronic medical conditions, and may cause fatigue, weakness, cramps, and arrhythmias. While supplementation can correct deficiency, it must be used cautiously since excessive potassium (hyperkalemia) can cause life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias. Over-the-counter potassium supplements are generally limited in dose due to safety concerns, with prescription formulations used for clinical management of hypokalemia.

metadata.natural_source: Fruits (bananas, oranges), vegetables (potatoes, spinach, tomatoes), legumes, whole grains

off_label_uses: Potential role in reducing kidney stone risk
contraindications: Use with potassium-sparing diuretics without monitoring

items: Maintains normal nerve conduction and muscle contraction

sections.text: Potassium is the major intracellular cation, essential for maintaining resting membrane potential, propagating action potentials, and balancing sodium to regulate fluid and blood pressure. In the heart, adequate potassium reduces risk of arrhythmias and stabilizes electrical conduction.

adult.typical: 20–100 mEq/day in divided doses for hypokalemia (prescription strength); dietary requirement ~2,600–3,400 mg/day
adult.note: OTC supplements usually limited to ≤99 mg per serving due to safety regulations.

sections.pediatric: Individualized based on body weight and deficiency status under clinical guidance.

sections.text: Correction of hypokalemia typically within hours to days; maintenance requires ongoing dietary intake or supplementation.

serious: Cardiac arrest (if overdosed or renal impairment present)

other: Excess supplementation may cause life-threatening arrhythmias.
Avoid high-dose use without medical monitoring, especially in kidney disease.

sections.pregnancy: Generally considered safe within dietary limits; supplementation requires supervision
sections.lactation: Safe in dietary amounts; supplement only if needed
sections.pediatrics: Use under supervision; dose-adjusted to body weight
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of hyperkalemia; monitor kidney function and medications

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinuation is safe once deficiency is corrected, but monitor potassium to avoid rebound changes.

items: OTC potassium supplements are limited to low doses due to risk of overdose.
Hypokalemia is commonly secondary to medications such as diuretics.
Dietary potassium is strongly associated with lower blood pressure and reduced stroke risk.
